tit.e: Opening of a country to the world
The opening of a country to the outside world
The opening of a country to the outside world

sen.j: 開国（かいこく）とは、鎖国の反対で外国と交際・貿易をすること。
sen.e: Opening of a country to the world which is contrary to national isolation means to interact and trade with foreign countries.
The opening of a country to the outside world (as opposed to national isolation) means to interact and trade with foreign countries.
The opening of a country to the outside world (as opposed to national isolation) means to interact and trade with foreign countries.

tit.e: Opening of China to the world
The opening of China to the outside world
The opening of China to the outside world

sen.j: 明王朝（1368年 - 1644年）は海禁を行い、倭寇などによる密貿易が行われた。
sen.e: Ming Dynasty (1368 – 1644) carried out Kaikin Policy (the policy to forbid private people to trade with foreign countries) and therefore wako (Japanese pirates) and others smuggled.
During the Ming Dynasty (1368-1644), China closed its seaports giving rise to an increase in illegal trade.
During the Ming Dynasty (1368-1644), China closed its seaports giving rise to an increase in illegal trade including one by wako (Japanese pirates).
sen.cmt: 「倭寇などによる」 訳漏れ対応しました。

sen.j: 清朝（1616年 - 1912年）も台湾の鄭成功勢力などに対抗するために海禁政策を行ったが、清朝は明朝と違い、厳格な海禁政策は取らなかった。
sen.e: Qing dynasty (1616 – 1912) also carried out Kaikin Policy, however unlike that of Ming Dynasty it was not strict.
A similar policy, though less strictly enforced, was carried out during Qing dynasty (1616-1912) in order to antagonize the Taiwanese ruler Zheng CHENGGONG.
A similar policy, though less strictly enforced, was carried out during Qing dynasty (1616-1912) in order to antagonize the Taiwanese ruler Zheng Chenggong.
sen.cmt: CHENGGONG→Chenggong余分なスペース削除しました。

sen.j: 特に台湾平定後は伝統的なポルトガル租借地マカオ以外に広州市も開港し、外国商船の来航も認めた。
sen.e: Especially after suppression of Taiwan, it opened traditional leased territory Macau as well as Guangzhou City and also accepted foreign merchant ships.
Following the suppression of Taiwan, ports accepting foreign merchant ships were opened in Macau as well as Guangzhou City.
Following the suppression of Taiwan, ports accepting foreign merchant ships were opened in Macau as well as Guangzhou City.
sen.cmt: 余分なスペース削除しました。

sen.j: このため18世紀には広州に欧米諸国の商館が設置され、広東貿易が行われた。
sen.e: Therefore in the 18th century, trading houses of Western countries were established and Canton Trade was carried on.
Thus, in the 18th century, Western trading houses were established in Guangzhou for the purpose of Cantonese trade.
Thus, in the 18th century, Western trading houses were established in Guangzhou for the purpose of Cantonese trade.
sen.cmt: 余分なスペース削除しました。序数表記を通常のものに変更しました。

sen.j: アヘン戦争（1840年 - 1842年）の敗北により結ばれた南京条約の締結（1842年）に続き、アロー号戦争（1857年 - 1860年）、清仏戦争（1884年 - 1885年）、日清戦争（1894年 - 1895年）、義和団の乱（19世紀末 - 20世紀初頭）といった事件が起こっていき、帝国主義列強に侵略されていくことになる。
sen.e: After defeated in the Opium War (1840 – 1842), it concluded Treaty of Nanjing and the Arrow War (1857 – 1860), the Sino-French War (1884 – 1885), the Japanese-Sino War (1894 – 1895) and the Giwadan War (the end of the 19th century – the early 20th century) followed that and the country was invaded by powerful countries of imperialism.

After concluding the Treaty of Nanjing following the Opium War (1840 – 1842), China endured the Arrow War (1857 – 1860), the Sino-French War (1884 – 1885), the Sino-Japanese War (1894 – 1895) and the Giwadan War (late19th century – early 20th century) before being invaded by powerful countries of imperialism.

After concluding the Treaty of Nanjing in 1842 following the Opium War (1840 – 1842), China endured the Arrow War (1857 – 1860), the Sino-French War (1884 – 1885), the Sino-Japanese War (1894 – 1895) and the Giwadan War (late 19th century – early 20th century) before being invaded by powerful countries of imperialism.
sen.cmt: (1842) 訳漏れ対応しました。late の後にスペースを入れました。

sen.j: イギリスに香港島を割譲、九竜・新界租借地、威海衛租借地を与え、ロシアに旅順大連租借地（後に日本が譲渡され関東州租借地）や東清鉄道利権を与え、ドイツに膠州湾租借地を、フランスに広州湾租借地を与えた他、日本に台湾を割譲した。
sen.e: It ceded Hong Kong Island and gave the leasehold lands in Kowloon and new territories as well as Weihaiwei to England and the leasehold lands in Dalian and Lushun (future the Kwantung Leased Territory of Japan) as well as Chinese Eastern Railway to Germany and the leased territory in Guangzhouwan to France and ceded Taiwan to Japan.

Hong Kong, Kowloon and Weihaiwei were ceded to England; Port Arthur in Dairen was ceded to Russia, Dalian, Lushun and the Chinese Eastern Railway were ceded to Germany, Guangzhouwan was ceded to France, and Taiwan was ceded to Japan.

Hong Kong Island was ceded to Great Britain, and Kowloon, the New Territories, and Weihaiwei were leased to this nation; the Lushun and Dalian Leased Territory (later ceded to Japan and renamed the Kwantung Leased Territory) was leased to Russia, and interests in the Eastern Chinese Railway were given to this nation; the Gouzhouwan Leased Territory was leased to Germany; the Kwangchowan Leased Territory was leased to France; and Taiwan was ceded to Japan.

sen.j: 上海市に共同租界やフランス租界が設置され、半植民地となっていく。
sen.e: In Shanghai, international settlement and French Concession were founded where became semi colonial.
Shanghai became semi colonial as several international concessions were established including one for France.
Shanghai became semi colonial as several international concessions were established including one for France.

sen.j: フランス租界の公園（現黄浦江沿いにある公園）に「犬と中国人入るべからず」という札が掲げられたのは、世界史における有名な逸話である。
sen.e: It is a famous anecdote in the world history that in the park of France Concession (along present Huangpu River) a sign 'Dogs and Chinese cannot enter' was set up.
A famous anecdote of world history tells of a sign posted in a park in the French Concession (along the present Huangpu River) which read 'Dogs and Chinese cannot enter'.
A famous anecdote of world history tells of a sign posted in a park in the French Concession (along the present Huangpu River) which read 'Dogs and Chinese cannot enter.'
sen.cmt: 余分なスペース削除しました。全角符号を半角に訂正しました。

tit.e: Opening of Japan to the world
The opening of Japan to the outside world
The opening of Japan to the outside world

sen.j: 日本は江戸時代に200年以上に渡って鎖国を続けており、対外的な窓は長崎の出島に限られ、日本人の海外渡航や大船建造の禁止など統制が行われていた。
sen.e: Japan was a closed country over 200 years in the Edo period and only Dejima in Nagasaki was opened to other countries and there were regulations such as ban on foreign voyage to Japanese and production of large ships.

Japan was a closed country for over 200 years in the Edo period with the exception of Dejima in Nagasaki which remained open to other countries; regulations such as a ban on foreign voyage to Japan and production of large ships were in effect.

Japan was a closed country for over 200 years in the Edo period with the exception of Dejima in Nagasaki which remained open to other countries; regulations such as a ban on foreign voyage to Japan and production of large ships were in effect.

sen.j: 18世紀には、主にロシア、イギリス、フランスなど帝国主義時代の欧米列強が日本へも接近し、日本人漂流民の返還のために蝦夷地へ来日したアダム・ラクスマンの来航（寛政4年（1792年））といった諸外国が通商を求める出来事や、1811年（文化8）のゴローニン事件といった摩擦・紛争が起こり始めた。
sen.e: In the 18th century, the allied western powers of imperialism such as Russia, England and France approached Japan and some issues and disputes started to occur such as the arrival of Adam Kirillovich Laksman who came to Ezo to return Japanese castaways in 1792 and the Golovnin Incident in 1811.

In the 18th century, the allied western powers of imperialism such as Russia, England and France approached Japan thus some issues and disputes started to occur such as the arrival of Adam Kirillovich Laksman who came to Ezo to return Japanese castaways in 1792 and the Golovnin Incident of 1811.

In the 18th century, the allied western powers of imperialism such as Russia, England and France approached Japan thus some issues and disputes started to occur such as the arrival of Adam Kirillovich Laksman who came to Ezo to return Japanese castaways in 1792 and the Golovnin Incident of 1811.
sen.cmt: 序数表記を変更しました。

sen.j: 幕府は1791年には寛政令、1806年には文化令がそれぞれ出され、来航した外国船に対して必要な物資を提供する政策が行われていた。
sen.e: Bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) issued Kanseirei (edict in Kansei era) in 1791 and Bunkarei (edict in Bunka era) as policies to provide foreign ships with necessary goods in Japan.
The Japanese feudal government issued various edicts in 1791 (Kanseirei) and 1806 (Bunkarei) which instituted a policy of providing necessities to foreign ships.
The bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) issued various edicts in 1791 (Kanseirei) and 1806 (Bunkarei) which instituted a policy of providing necessities to foreign ships.
sen.cmt: ＮＣにより訂正された「幕府」の表記を定訳どおりに戻しました。

sen.j: 25年には一転して強硬な異国船打払令（文政令）が出され、文化5年（1808年）にはイギリス船が長崎へ上陸して食料を奪うフェートン号事件が起こり、1837年には浦賀に侵入したアメリカ商船に大砲が打たれるモリソン号事件が起こる。
sen.e: In contrast, a strict edict, Order for the Repelling of Foreign Ships was issued in 1825 and in 1808 the Phaeton Incident occurred that a British ship arrived in Nagasaki robbed food and in 1837 the Morrison Incident occurred that an American ship entered in Uraga was attacked with cannon.

In a turn of events, a strict edict known as the Order for the Repelling of Foreign Ships was issued in 1825 following the 1808 Phaeton Incident in which a British ship pillaged food in Nagasaki; by 1837 the Morrison Incident occurred in which an American ship sailing into Uraga was attacked by cannon.

In a turn of events, a strict edict known as the Order for the Repelling of Foreign Ships was issued in 1825 following the 1808 Phaeton Incident in which a British ship pillaged food in Nagasaki; by 1837 the Morrison Incident occurred in which an American ship sailing into Uraga was attacked by cannon.

sen.j: 幕府の対外情報源は、出島において貿易を許可されていた中国（清）とオランダの「風説書」が主であった。
sen.e: Bakufu received information about foreign countries from countries that were allowed to trade in Dejima, such as China (Qing) and the Netherlands that provided 'Fusetsugaki' (documents about foreign information).

The feudal government received information about foreign countries from countries that were allowed to trade in Dejima, such as China (Qing) and the Netherlands which provided 'Fusetsugaki' (documents about foreign information).

The bakufu received information about foreign countries from countries that were allowed to trade in Dejima, such as China (Qing) and the Netherlands which provided 'Fusetsugaki' (documents about foreign information).
sen.cmt: 全角符号を半角に訂正しました。幕府を「the bakufu」に訂正しました。

sen.j: アヘン戦争で中国の清が敗北したことが伝わる（1842年）と、老中の水野忠邦は1842年に令を緩和する（天保の薪水令）。
sen.e: When roju (senior councillor of the Tokugawa shogunate) Tadakuni MIZUNO heard the Qing's defeat in the Opium War in 1842, he loosened the order Shinsui (fuel and water) rei (Shinsuirei in Tenpo).
When roju (senior councillor of the Tokugawa shogunate) Tadakuni MIZUNO heard in 1842 of the China's defeat in the Opium War, he loosened restrictions on fuel and water.
When roju (member of shogun's council of elders) Tadakuni MIZUNO heard in 1842 of the China's defeat in the Opium War, he loosened restrictions on fuel and water.
sen.cmt: 全角符号を半角に訂正しました。老中の定訳

sen.j: 44年にはオランダのヴィレム2世 (オランダ王)が開国を勧める親書を送る。
sen.e: In 1844, Willem II (king of the Netherlands) sent a letter recommending to open the country to bakufu.
In 1844, Willem II (king of the Netherlands) sent a letter encouraging the feudal government to open the country.
In 1844, Willem II (king of the Netherlands) sent a letter encouraging the feudal government to open the country.

sen.j: アメリカ合衆国は石炭補給基地の確保や、日本沿岸で漂流した自国民やその財産の保護、日本との自由貿易などの理由で日本との通商を試みていた。
sen.e: The United States of America tried to commerce with Japan to secure a coal supply-base, to protect American castaways in Japan and their property and to trade with Japan freely.
The United States of America reached out Japan for the purpose of establishing free trade, securing a coal supply-base, and protecting American castaways and their property in Japan.

The United States of America reached out Japan for the purpose of establishing free trade, securing a coal supply-base, and protecting American castaways and their property, and freely trading with Japan.
sen.cmt: 「日本との自由貿易」がＮＣにより削除されていたため、文末部分に再び加えました。

sen.j: 1846年（弘化3）、東インド艦隊司令長官ジェームズ・ビッドルを派遣して国交を求めたが、江戸幕府はこれを拒絶し、46年の米墨戦争の勃発のため帰国する。
sen.e: In 1846, East India fleet admiral James BIDDLE was sent to Japan seeking diplomatic relations, but Edo bakufu refused it and he went back to his country because of Mexican-American War in the same year.

In 1846, East India fleet admiral James BIDDLE was sent to Japan seeking diplomatic relations, but the Edo government refused and he went back to his country because of the outbreak of the Mexican-American War.
In 1846, East India fleet admiral James BIDDLE was sent to Japan seeking diplomatic relations, but the Edo bakufu and he went back to his country because of the outbreak of the Mexican-American War.
sen.cmt: 余分なスペース削除しました。幕府の表記を戻しました。

sen.j: 49年3月には漂流民ラナルド・マクドナルドの返還を求めるプレブル号が来航し、長崎奉行の仲介で解決する。
sen.e: In March 1849, The ship Preble arrived to demand the return of a castaway Ranald MacDonald and it was resolved at the mediation of Nagasaki bugyo.
In March 1849, The ship Preble arrived to demand the return of a castaway Ranald MACDONALD which was resolved by the mediation of Nagasaki magistrate.
In March 1849, The ship Preble arrived to demand the return of a castaway Ranald MACDONALD which was resolved by the mediation of Nagasaki magistrate.

sen.j: この頃には「風説書」により、アメリカより通商を求める使節が来航する情報が幕府に伝わっている。
sen.e: At that time, bakufu already knew the information trough 'Fusetsugaki' that an envoy would arrive to seek commerce.
At that time, feudal government was already aware from a 'Fusetsugaki'(document about foreign information) that an American envoy would arrive seeking commerce.
At that time, feudal government was already aware from a 'Fusetsugaki' that an American envoy would arrive seeking commerce.
sen.cmt: 既出単語の説明削除しました。全角符号を半角に訂正しました。

sen.j: 嘉永6年（1853年）6月、アメリカは再び東インド艦隊司令長官に任命されたマシュー・ペリーを派遣する。
sen.e: In June 1853, the United States of America dispatched Matthew (Calbraith) PERRY who was assigned as an East India fleet admiral.
In June 1853, the United States of America dispatched Matthew (Calbraith) PERRY who was assigned as an East India fleet admiral.
In June 1853, the United States of America dispatched Matthew (Calbraith) PERRY who was assigned as an East India fleet admiral.

sen.j: ペリーは共和党 (アメリカ)のミラード・フィルモア大統領から海軍の作戦行動として日本との条約締結を命じられるが、アメリカでは交戦権が上院に属するため、発砲は禁止されていた。
sen.e: Perry was ordered to conclude a treaty with Japan as an operation of navy by Republican and president Millard Fillmore, but firing was prohibited because the Senate had the right of belligerency.
PERRY had been ordered by Republican president Millard FILLMORE on a naval mission to conclude a treaty with Japan, but was prohibited from any act of belligerency without senate approval.
Perry had been ordered by Republican president Millard FILLMORE on a naval mission to conclude a treaty with Japan, but was prohibited from any act of belligerency without senate approval.

sen.j: ペリーは蒸気船を配備した東インド艦隊を引きいて、53年7月に浦賀沖に来航し、7月14日に久里浜に設置された開国を求めるアメリカ大統領国書を提出し、9日後に帰国。
sen.e: Perry arrived at Uraga with East India fleet deployed steamboats in July 1853 and submitted a sovereign's message from the president of the US demanding to open the country on July 14 and returned to the US after 9 days.

PERRY arrived at Uraga at the head of a fleet of East India steamboats in July 1853 and submitted a message from the president of the US demanding the opening the country on July 14, returning to the US 9 days later.

Perry arrived at Uraga at the head of a fleet of East India steamboats in July 1853 and submitted a message from the president of the US demanding the opening the country on July 14, returning to the US 9 days later.
sen.cmt: PERRY→Perry余分なスペース削除「久里浜に設置された」が訳出されていませんが、この意味がよくわかりませんので、省かれたのかと思います。

sen.j: 7月にはロシアのプチャーチン艦隊が長崎へ来航。
sen.e: In July Putyatin fleet from Russia arrived at Nagasaki.
In July of that same year the Putyatin fleet from Russia arrived at Nagasaki.
In July of that same year the Putyatin fleet from Russia arrived at Nagasaki.

sen.j: 江戸幕府では老中阿部正弘らを中心に、7月31日に国書を開封、諸大名から庶民まで幅広く意見を求めた。
sen.e: Edo bakufu centring on roju Masahiro ABE opened the sovereign's message on July 31 and asked for opinions widely from territorial lords to the common people.
The Edo feudal government, lead by it's senior councillor Masahiro ABE, upon opening the president's message on July 31 sought advice far and wide from territorial lords to the common people.
The Edo bakufu, lead by it's roju Masahiro ABE, upon opening the president's message on July 31 sought advice far and wide from territorial lords to the common people.
sen.cmt: 幕府と老中の表記を戻しました。

sen.j: 先例を破って朝廷に事態を報告、対策を協議して日米和親条約を結び、下田港と函館港を開港し、9月には大船建造の禁を緩和、10月には海外渡航が解禁される。
sen.e: Breaking precedent, bakufu reported the state of affairs to Imperial Court, discussed measures, concluded Treaty between the United States of America and the Empire of Japan, opened Shimoda and Hakodate Ports, loosened Ban on production of large ships in September and lifted its ban on foreign voyage in October.

In an unprecedented move, the feudal government reported the state of affairs to the Imperial Court, where the matter was discussed until a treaty between the United States of America and the Empire of Japan was concluded which opened ports at Shimoda and Hakodate, loosened a ban on production of large ships as of September and lifted the ban on foreign voyage by October.

In an unprecedented move, the bakufu reported the state of affairs to the Imperial Court, where the matter was discussed until a treaty between the United States of America and the Empire of Japan was concluded which opened ports at Shimoda and Hakodate, loosened a ban on production of large ships as of September and lifted the ban on foreign voyage by October.
sen.cmt: 幕府の表記を戻しました。余分なスペース削除しました。

sen.j: さらにオランダ商館に蒸気船を発注し、60年には勝海舟ら咸臨丸を派遣する。
sen.e: Also it ordered steamboats to Dutch trading house and dispatched Kanrin Maru Warship of Kaishu KATSU and others in 1860.
In addition, steamboats were sent to Dutch trading houses while warships, including the Kanrin-maru helmed by Kaishu KATSU, were dispatched in 1860.
In addition, steamboats were placed an order with Dutch trading houses while the Kanrin-maru helmed by Kaishu KATSU was dispatched in 1860.
sen.cmt: sent to→placed an order withwarships, including the Kanrin-maru→the Kanrin-maru.were→was

sen.j: 1854年1月、琉球や小笠原諸島などを回航していたペリーが国書の返答を求めるため、再び浦賀へ来航。
sen.e: In January 1854, Perry was cruising in Ryukyu and Ogasawara Islands (Bonin Islands) and arrived at Uraga again to ask the answer to the sovereign's message.
Upon cruising the Ryukyu and Ogasawara Islands (Bonin Islands), PERRY returned to Uraga in January 1954 seeking a reply to the president's message.
Upon cruising the Ryukyu and Ogasawara Islands (Bonin Islands), Perry returned to Uraga in January 1854 seeking a reply to the president's message.

sen.j: 3月に日米和親条約が、8月には日英和親条約が、12月には日露和親条約がそれぞれ締結される。
sen.e: In March Treaty between the United States of America and the Empire of Japan, in August Anglo-Japanese Friendship Treaty and in December Treaty between the Russian Empire and the Empire of Japan were concluded respectively.

In March 1854, a treaty between the United States of America and the Empire of Japan was signed, followed by the Anglo-Japanese Friendship Treaty in August as well as a treaty with the Russian Empire as of December the same year.

In March 1854, a treaty between the United States of America and the Empire of Japan was signed, followed by the Anglo-Japanese Friendship Treaty in August as well as a treaty with the Russian Empire as of December the same year.

sen.j: 安政3年（1856年）7月、アメリカ領事タウンゼント・ハリスが修好通商条約締結のため来日し、57年10月には江戸城へ登城。
sen.e: In July 1856, American consul Townsend HARRIS came to Japan to conclude a treaty of amity and came to Edo-jo Castle in October 1857.
In July 1856, American consul Townsend HARRIS came to Japan to conclude a treaty of amity visiting Edo-jo Castle in October 1857.
In July 1856, American consul Townsend HARRIS came to Japan to conclude a treaty of amity visiting Edo-jo Castle in October 1857.

sen.j: 老中堀田正睦はこれを京都の朝廷に上奏したが勅許を得られず、13代将軍徳川家定の将軍継嗣問題とも関係して南紀派、一橋派の抗争となる。
sen.e: Roju Masayoshi HOTTA reported it to the Court in Kyoto, however he couldn't get the imperial permission and also a problem of heir of the 13th shogun Iesada TOKUGAWA occurred and Nanki group (group supporting Yoshitomi from the Kisyu-Tokugawa family) and Hitotsubashi group (group supporting Yoshinobu from the Hitotsubashi-Tokugawa family) entered on a struggle.

Although the treaty was brought to the court in Kyoto by senior councillor Masayoshi HOTTA, it was not signed due to a struggle of succession concerning the heir of the 13th shogun Iesada TOKUGAWA between the Nanki group (Yoshitomi loyalists from the Kishu-Tokugawa family) and the Hitotsubashi group (Yoshinobu loyalists from the Hitotsubashi-Tokugawa family).

Although the treaty was brought to the court in Kyoto by roju Masayoshi HOTTA, it was not signed due to a struggle of succession concerning the heir of the 13th shogun Iesada TOKUGAWA between the Nanki group (Yoshitomi loyalists from the Kishu-Tokugawa family) and the Hitotsubashi group (Yoshinobu loyalists from the Hitotsubashi-Tokugawa family).
sen.cmt: 老中の表記を戻しました。余分なスペース削除しました。

sen.j: 58年に大老に就任した井伊直弼は、日米修好通商条約を締結、紀伊国藩主徳川家茂を14代将軍にした。
sen.e: In 1858 Naosuki II became tairo (chief minister) and concluded the Treaty of Amity and Commerce between the United States and Japan and set the lord of Ki Province Iemochi TOKUGAWA up as the 14th shogun.

In 1858 Naosuki II became tairo (chief minister) and concluded the Treaty of Amity and Commerce between the United States and Japan and set the lord of Ki Province Iemochi TOKUGAWA up as the 14th shogun.

In 1858 Naosuke II became tairo (chief minister) and concluded the Treaty of Amity and Commerce between the United States and Japan and set the lord of Kii Province Iemochi TOKUGAWA up as the 14th shogun.

sen.j: （→安政の大獄、桜田門外の変参照）
sen.e: (Refer to Ansei no Taigoku and the Sakuradamongai Incident)
(Refer to Ansei no Taigoku (suppression of extremists by the Shogunate) and the Sakuradamongai Incident)
(Refer to Ansei no Taigoku [suppression of extremists by the Shogunate] and the Sakuradamongai Incident)
sen.cmt: 括弧内の括弧を[]に変更しました。

sen.j: 59年には箱館、横浜港、長崎港、新潟港、神戸港の5港を開港し（下田を閉鎖）、江戸や大阪などの市場が開放されて貿易が開始され、貿易相手国は主にイギリスであった。
sen.e: In 1859, 5 ports including Hakodate Port, Yokohama Port, Nagasaki Port, Nigata Port, Kobe Port (Shimoda Port was closed) were opened and the markets such as Edo and Osaka were opened and started to trade mainly with England.

In 1859, 5 ports including Hakodate Port, Yokohama Port, Nagasaki Port, Nigata Port, Kobe Port (Shimoda Port was closed) were opened thus markets in cities such as Edo and Osaka were opened and started to trade primarily with England.

In 1859, five ports including Hakodate Port, Yokohama Port, Nagasaki Port, Niigata Port, Kobe Port (Shimoda Port was closed) were opened thus markets in cities such as Edo and Osaka were opened and started to trade primarily with England.

sen.j: 日本からは生糸や茶などが輸出され、毛織物、綿織物や艦船や武器などが輸入された。
sen.e: Japan exported raw silk thread, tea and others and imported wool, cotton fabric, warships, weapons and others.
Japan exported primarily raw silk thread and tea while mainly importing wool, cotton fabric, warships, and weapons.
Japan exported primarily raw silk thread and tea while mainly importing wool, cotton fabric, warships, and weapons.

sen.j: 日米修好通商条約は「治外法権」、関税自主権の放棄（協定関税率制）、片務的最恵国待遇など、日本にとって不利な内容を含む不平等条約であり、無防備なままの日本市場が世界市場に対して開かれると、入過により国内産業への影響、金の流出が物価高騰、尊王攘夷運動の激化や一揆、打ちこわし等を招いた。
sen.e: The Treaty of Amity and Commerce between the United States and Japan was an unequal treaty including unfavourable conditions against Japan such as 'extraterritoriality', renunciation of tariff autonomy (tariff agreement system) and unilateral MFN, therefore when the Japanese market was opened to the world defencelessly, domestic industries had the impact and prices increased by drain of gold and Sonno Joi Movement (the Movement advocating reverence for the Emperor and the expulsion of foreigners), uprising and destructive urban riots occurred.

The Treaty of Amity and Commerce between the United States and Japan was seen by Japan as an unequal treaty including unfavourable conditions against Japan such as extraterritoriality, resignation of tariff autonomy (tariff agreement system) and unilateral MFN (most favoured nation) status, therefore when the Japanese market was opened to the world, domestic industries were defenceless against the impact of price increases and the draining of gold reserves which gave rise to the Sonno Joi Movement (a movement advocating reverence to the Emperor and expulsion of foreigners), uprising, and destructive urban riots.

The Treaty of Amity and Commerce between the United States and Japan was an unequal treaty including unfavourable conditions against Japan such as extraterritoriality, resignation of tariff autonomy (tariff agreement system) and unilateral MFN (most favoured nation) status, therefore when the Japanese market was opened to the world, domestic industries were defenceless against the impact of price increases and the draining of gold reserves which gave rise to the Sonno Joi Movement (a movement advocating reverence to the Emperor and expulsion of foreigners), uprising, and destructive urban riots.
sen.cmt: 「seen by Japan as」がＮＣにより加えられていますが、削除しました。

sen.j: 幕府は物価高騰と流通の混乱を防ぐため、60年に五品江戸廻送令を発して貿易の統制を図ろうとするが失敗する。
sen.e: To prevent from price increase and confusion in distribution, in 1860 bakufu issued a regulation to control of foreign trade called Gohin Edo Kaisorei, but it was unsuccessful.
To prevent price increases and confusion in distribution, in 1860 the feudal government issued a regulation to control foreign trade called the Gohin Edo Kaisorei, which proved unsuccessful.
To prevent price increases and confusion in distribution, in 1860 the bakufu issued a regulation to control foreign trade called the Gohin Edo Kaisorei, which proved unsuccessful.
sen.cmt: 幕府の表記を戻しました。

sen.j: 条約港となった横浜、神戸、長崎などでは外国人居留地（実質的な租界）も設置された。
sen.e: Foreign settlements were established in treaty ports in Yokohama, Kobe and Nagasaki.
Foreign settlements were established in treaty ports in Yokohama, Kobe and Nagasaki.
Foreign settlements were established in treaty ports in Yokohama, Kobe and Nagasaki.

sen.j: 明治政府の外交政策にとって、この是正は重要な課題のひとつとなるが、逆に一部の国粋主義者からは居留地の存在が外国の思想や宗教から日本の伝統・文化を守る防壁になっているという見地からの存続論も登場して複雑な論争を招くことになった（内地雑居）。
sen.e: For the Meiji government, this correction was one of the important issues, on the other hand some nationalist advocated that the settlements became a wall to protect Japanese tradition and culture from foreign ideas and religions and complicated dispute arose (Naichi Zakkyo).

While this change was an important policy issue for the Meiji government, complicated disputes arose among some nationalists as to whether the settlements acted as a bulwark protecting Japanese tradition and culture from foreign ideas and religion.

While this change was an important policy issue for the Meiji government, complicated disputes arose among some nationalists as to whether the settlements acted as a bulwark protecting Japanese tradition and culture from foreign ideas and religion.
sen.cmt: 文末の括弧書きがＮＣにより削除されていますがＯＫと考えます。余分なスペース削除しました。

sen.j: 同様の条約がイギリス、フランス、オランダ、ロシアとも結ばれた（安政五ヶ国条約）。
sen.e: Same treaties were concluded with England, France, the Netherlands and Russia (Ansei Gokakoku Joyaku).
Similar treaties were concluded with England, France, the Netherlands and Russia.
Similar treaties were concluded with England, France, the Netherlands and Russia.

sen.j: 江戸幕府を倒した薩摩藩・長州藩などの攘夷派を中心とした明治政府も、明治2年（1869年）に政府として改めて開国を決定して、以後は不平等条約の撤廃（条約改正）が外交課題となっていくことになる。
sen.e: The Meiji government centering on Joi-ha such as Satsuma clan and Choshu clan, which defeated Edo bakufu, decided to open the country in 1869 and after that abolishment of unequal treaty (treaty revision) was the diplomacy issue.
The Meiji government, lead by the Satsuma and Choshu clans, which had defeated the Edo feudal government, decided to open the country in 1869 and abolish the unequal treaties..
The Meiji government, lead by the Satsuma and Choshu clans, which had defeated the Edo bakufu, decided to open the country in 1869 and abolish the unequal treaties..
sen.cmt: 幕府の表記を戻しました。

sen.j: 日本は開国により帝国主義時代の欧米列強と国際関係を持つこととなる。
sen.e: By opening the country, Japan had international relationships with the allied western powers of imperialism.
By opening the country, Japan established international relationships with the allied western powers of imperialism.
By opening the country, Japan established international relationships with the allied western powers of imperialism.

tit.e: Opening of Korea to the world
The opening of Korea to the outside world
The opening of Korea to the outside world

sen.j: 李氏朝鮮（1392年 - 1910年）末期の1832年イギリスが通商を求めに現れ、1840年頃からヨーロッパ船が近海に頻繁に出没するようになった。
sen.e: In 1832 at the end of Yi Dynasty (1392 – 1910), England appeared to seek commerce and since 1840 European ships appeared frequently in the sea around the country.
In 1832 towards the end of Yi Dynasty (1392 – 1910), England arrived seeking commerce and from 1840 onwards European ships appeared frequently along the Korean coast.
In 1832 towards the end of Yi Dynasty (1392 – 1910), England arrived seeking commerce and from 1840 onwards European ships appeared frequently along the Korean coast.

sen.j: 19世紀頃朝鮮では勢道政治（王の外戚による政治）が行われていた。
sen.e: In the 19th century, sedo jeongchi (government by the maternal relative of a king) was conducted in Korea.
In the 19th century, Sedo Jeongchi (monarchy of matrilineal succession) was practiced in Korea.
In the 19th century, Sedo Jeongchi (monarchy of matrilineal succession) was practiced in Korea.

sen.j: 1863年から李朝第26代高宗 (朝鮮王)（在位1863年 - 1907年）の父で摂政の興宣大院君による政権時代、迫り来る帝国主義列強を排除する政策をとっていた。
sen.e: From 1863, the regime of the father of the 26th king of Yi Dynasty Gao Zong (reign 1863 – 1907), regent Kosen Daiinkun implemented a policy to remove coming powerful countries of imperialism.

In 1863, Kosen DAIINKUN, regent of the regime of the father of the 26th king of Yi Dynasty of Gao Zong (reign 1863 – 1907), implemented a policy to exclude the coming powerful countries of imperialism.

In 1863, Heungseon Daewongun, regent of the regime of the father of the 26th king of Yi Dynasty of Gao Zong (reign 1863 – 1907), implemented a policy to exclude the coming powerful countries of imperialism.
sen.cmt: Kosen DAIINKUN→Heungseon Daewongun（用語集より）序数を通常の表記としました。余分なスペース削除しました。

sen.j: 1866年ジェネラル・シャーマン号事件（対アメリカ合衆国）、丙寅洋擾（対フランス）、1868年日本（明治政府）からの国書（明治政府の樹立宣言、王政復古の通告）の受け取りを拒否する、1871年辛未洋擾（対アメリカ）、など、海禁政策をとった（鎖国攘夷策）。
sen.e: It implemented Kaikin policy (national isolation and expulsion of foreigners) such as General Sherman incident (against the US) and Heiinyojo war (against France) in 1866, refusal to receive sovereign's message (declaration of the Meiji government foundation and the restoration of Imperial rule) from Japan (the Meiji government) in 1868 and Shinmiyojo incident (against the US) in 1871.

An isolationist policy was implemented resulting in the General Sherman incident (against the US) as well as the Heiinyojo war (against France) in 1866, the refusal of the declaration of the foundation of the Meiji government from Japan in 1868 and Shinmiyojo incident (against the US) in 1871.

An isolationist policy was implemented resulting in the General Sherman incident (against the US) as well as the Heiinyojo war (against France) in 1866, the refusal of the declaration of the foundation of the Meiji government from Japan in 1868 and Shinmiyojo incident (against the US) in 1871.
sen.cmt: 「王政復古」等がＮＣによって省かれていますが、簡潔にまとめられていて、ＯＫと考えます。

sen.j: 1873年朝鮮政府の実権は閔妃（1851年 - 1895年、高宗の妃）一族に移った。
sen.e: In 1873 the real power of Korean government transferred to the family of Empress Myeongseong (1851 – 1895, the empress of Gao Zong).
In 1873 reign of the Korean government transferred to the family of Empress Myeongseong (1851 – 1895), the empress of Gao Zong.
In 1873 reign of the Korean government transferred to the family of Empress Myeongseong (1851 – 1895), the empress of Gao Zong.

sen.j: こうした中で1875年江華島事件（雲楊号事件）が起こる。
sen.e: In such a situation, Ganghwa Island incident (Unyogo incident) occurred in 1875.
Within this context, Ganghwa Island incident occurred in 1875.
Within this context, Ganghwa Island incident (Unyogo incident) occurred in 1875.
sen.cmt: 削除された (Unyogo incident) を戻しました。

sen.j: 日本政府が示威で江華島沖に送った軍艦雲揚 (軍艦)から出た小船に江華島の砲台から発砲、雲揚が「応戦」した事件である。
sen.e: It was an incident that a boat of the battle ship Unyo which was sent to Ganghwa Island by Japanese government as demonstration of strength was attacked with cannon from Ganghwa Island and Unyo 'returned' fire.

The incident occurred when a Japanese battleship, the Unyo, sent a small boat to Ganghwa Island as a demonstration of strength by the Japanese government and was attacked by cannon from Ganghwa Island whereupon the battleship 'returned' fire.

The incident occurred when a Japanese battleship, the Unyo, sent a small boat to Ganghwa Island as a demonstration of strength by the Japanese government and was attacked by cannon from Ganghwa Island whereupon the battleship 'returned' fire.
sen.cmt: 全角符号を半角に訂正しました。

sen.j: 雲揚が許可なく朝鮮の領海を侵犯したので、これを排除しようとしたものである。
sen.e: Because Unyo violated Korean waters without any permission, it was attacked to remove.
Because the Unyo entered Korean waters without permission, it was repelled by Korean forces.
Because the Unyo entered Korean waters without permission, it was repelled by Korean forces.

sen.j: しかし日本政府はこれを口実として砲艦外交を押し出し、1876年江華島条約（日朝修好条規）が結ばれる。
sen.e: However, Japanese government conducted gunboat diplomacy with an excuse for that, in 1876 Treaty of Ganghwa (Japanese-Korea Treaty of Amity) was concluded.
The Japanese government, using the incident as a pretext for gunboat diplomacy, concluded the Treaty of Ganghwa (Japanese-Korea Treaty of Amity) in 1876.
The Japanese government, using the incident as a pretext for gunboat diplomacy, concluded the Treaty of Ganghwa (Japanese-Korea Treaty of Amity) in 1876.

sen.j: 釜山広域市・元山市・仁川広域市の3港を開港、ソウル特別市に日本公使館を開設した。
sen.e: Tree ports in Busan Metropolitan City, Wonsan-si and Incheon Metropolitan City were opened and Japan legation was established in Seoul Metropolitan City.
Ports were opened in Busan, Wonsan, and Incheon while a Japanese legation was established in Seoul.
Ports were opened in Busan, Wonsan, and Incheon while a Japanese legation was established in Seoul.

sen.j: これは中国がイギリスと結んだ南京条約（1842年）、日本がアメリカと結んだ日米修好通商条約（1858年）と同様、治外法権の認定など、結ばされた側にとっての不平等条約であった。
sen.e: As Nanjin Treaty between China and England in 1842 and the Treaty of Amity and Commerce between the United States and Japan in 1858, it was an unequal treaty with extraterritoriality and others for Korea.

Similar to the Treaty of Nanjing between China and England of 1842 and the Treaty of Amity and Commerce concluded between the United States and Japan in 1858, it was an unequal treaty for Korea as it granted extraterritoriality amongst other provisions.

Similar to the Treaty of Nanjing between China and England of 1842 and the Treaty of Amity and Commerce concluded between the United States and Japan in 1858, it was an unequal treaty for Korea as it granted extraterritoriality amongst other provisions.

sen.j: 続いて1882年に米朝修好通商条約を締結し、さらにイギリス・ドイツ・ロシア・フランスとも同様の条約を結んだ。
sen.e: Subsequently in 1882, US-Korea Amity and Trade Treaty were concluded and also same treaties were concluded with England, Germany, Russia and France.
Subsequently in 1882, the US-Korea Amity and Trade Treaty was concluded as were similar treaties with England, Germany, Russia and France.
Subsequently in 1882, the US-Korea Amity and Trade Treaty was concluded as were similar treaties with England, Germany, Russia and France.

sen.j: これによって朝鮮は、帝国主義が渦巻く世界へ開国していくことになった。
sen.e: As the result, Korea opened to the world of imperialism
As a result, Korea was opened to the world of imperialism.
As a result, Korea was opened to the world of imperialism.

sen.j: 一方、江華島条約の第1条には「朝鮮は自主独立の国であり、日本と平等な権利を有する」とあり、朝鮮は従来もっていた華夷秩序との葛藤が起こっていく。
sen.e: On the other hand, the first article of Treaty of Ganghwa stated 'Korea is an independent country having the equal right to Japan', which caused a conflict with the Chinese Suzerainty over Korea.
On the other hand, the first article of the Treaty of Ganghwa stated 'Korea is an independent country having rights equal to Japan', which caused a conflict with the Chinese hegemony over Korea.
On the other hand, the first article of the Treaty of Ganghwa stated 'Korea is an independent country having rights equal to Japan,' which caused a conflict with the Chinese hegemony over Korea.
sen.cmt: 全角符号を半角に訂正しました。

sen.j: 華夷秩序：中国を中心とした東アジアにおける秩序。
sen.e: The Chinese Suzerainty over Korea: on order in East Asia centring China.
The Chinese hegemony over Korea: a Sino-centric rule of East Asia.
The Chinese hegemony over Korea: a Sino-centric rule of East Asia.

sen.j: 冊封体制。
sen.e: Tributary system.
Tributary system.
Tributary system.

sen.j: 東アジア（朝鮮・日本を含む中国の周囲の諸国）では近代の開国前後、万国公法という概念との葛藤を経験することになる。
sen.e: In East Asia (various districts around China including Korea and Japan), there was a conflict with modern notions such as Kaikoku Zengo (before and after opening a county) and Bankoku Koho (International Law).
East Asia (including Korea, Japan, and many regions within China), experienced conflicts with modern notions regarding international law and the opening of countries to the outside world.

East Asia (including Korea, Japan, and many regions around China), experienced conflicts with notions regarding international law around the time of the modern opening of countries to the outside world.
sen.cmt: modern notions regarding international law and the→notions regarding international law around the time of the modern 「近代の開国前後」の解釈が翻訳者と異なります。within→around余分なスペース削除しました。
